Create [PROFILE COUNT: 3–5] prioritized Board Recruitment Profiles for [ORGANIZATION NAME] to guide strategic, inclusive board recruitment aligned to mission.

The Board Recruitment Profiles should:
- Start with a one-line title and a 1–2 sentence “Why this profile now” tied to [STRATEGIC PRIORITIES FOR 12–24 MONTHS] and current board gaps.
- Specify “Must-have” and “Nice-to-have” skills and lived experience based on a skills matrix (e.g., finance, legal, HR, fundraising, program/domain expertise), not generic traits.
- State diversity/perspective needs using inclusive, non-tokenizing language; explain why the perspective benefits governance and community accountability.
- Detail responsibilities and realistic time commitment: [MEETING CADENCE], committee(s), prep hours/month, events, and estimated annual hours; note [HYBRID/REMOTE] and [GEOGRAPHY] expectations.
- Clarify fundraising role: explicit [GIVE/GET] (if any), examples of non-monetary fundraising actions (peer introductions, hosting small gatherings, storytelling, advocacy).
- Include governance basics: [TERM LENGTH], onboarding timeline, conflict-of-interest and fiduciary duties, any [LEGAL/FINANCIAL REQUIREMENTS].
- Describe support offered: staff liaison, board mentor, training (governance/fundraising), accessibility/accommodations, and how busy professionals can succeed.
- Outline selection criteria and vetting steps: values alignment, references, conflict check, sample screening questions (3–5).
- Suggest 3–6 targeted sourcing avenues: relevant associations, community partners, alumni/affinity groups, volunteer leaders, client/participant leaders (as appropriate).
- Provide a 75–100 word outreach blurb tailored to this profile.
- Use [TONE]: FORMAL (policy-aligned, precise), WARM (community-centered, inviting), or CASUAL (plain-language, friendly).
- List author/signatory and contact: [AUTHOR: Board Governance Committee/Board Chair/ED], [CONTACT EMAIL]; add “Review by [DATE]” for annual refresh.

Each profile should be 250–350 words plus the outreach blurb and screening questions. Produce clear, concrete expectations; avoid clichés (“rockstar,” “work hard/play hard”), jargon, and tokenizing language. Aim for focus: prioritize what the board truly needs now, be transparent about time and fundraising expectations, and write so a small team can recruit confidently without a search firm.

## **PROFILE 1: Bilingual Community Builder with Nonprofit HR/Volunteer Systems Experience**

**Why this profile now:** As we launch mobile tutoring sites and implement a new volunteer CRM system, we need someone who understands bilingual program operations and volunteer management systems to ensure our expansion serves families equitably and sustainably.

### Must-Have Skills & Experience
- Professional experience in HR, volunteer coordination, or nonprofit operations (3+ years)
- Familiarity with volunteer management systems, database implementation, or CRM platforms
- Working proficiency in Spanish (conversational minimum; professional fluency preferred)
- Track record managing or supporting bilingual programs or culturally responsive services

- Experience with VolunteerHub, Salesforce, or similar platforms
- Background in adult education, literacy, or family services
- Grant reporting or compliance experience
- Live or work in Jefferson County (Madras/Metolius area)

### Why This Perspective Matters
Our learner base is 60% Latinx, but our board currently lacks Spanish-speaking members who can review materials, participate in community listening sessions, and advise on culturally grounded outreach. This perspective ensures our volunteer systems and mobile sites reflect the lived realities of the families we serve, strengthening both program quality and community accountability.

### Board Service Expectations
- **Meetings:** Board meets every other month (6x/year) on Thursday evenings, 6:00–8:00 p.m.; Governance or Programs Committee meets monthly (alternating months)
- **Prep & engagement:** ~4 hours/month (meeting prep, emails, occasional site visit)

- **Location:** Hybrid—primarily in person in Prineville or Madras, with Zoom available. Board members within a 90-minute drive preferred.

- Non-monetary actions welcomed: host a small house party for 8–10 friends to learn about our work; share appeal on personal social channels; invite a colleague to tour a mobile site

- **Term:** Two years, renewable up to three terms (max 6 years)
- **Onboarding:** Three-session onboarding over first 60 days (governance 101, program tour, financial overview) with board mentor assigned
- **Policies:** Annual conflict-of-interest disclosure; background check (interacts with learners at events); sign confidentiality policy

Even busy professionals thrive here. You'll receive:
- Dedicated staff liaison (Programs Director) and board mentor
- Pre-meeting packets delivered 5 days ahead; all materials in Google Drive
- Governance training stipend ($150 for workshop/webinar of choice in Year 1)
- Childcare reimbursement and interpretation available for all meetings
- Flexible attendance: Zoom option for up to 2 meetings/year if needed

We seek alignment with our values: equity, community-driven service, transparency, and belonging. We'll ask for two references, conduct a conflict-of-interest check, and invite a casual conversation with the Governance Committee.
